ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed the ability to critically observe and evaluate wealth, wealthy families, wealthy people, and wealthy institutions. I learned how to more efficiently see wealthy people and institutions interact with the world, and the effects that those interactions have.
This was a really interesting and organized course! Prof. Ramos-Zayas is very kind and helpful.

I learned about wealth in the Americas--institutions that uphold it, how to spot/critically analyze it, the lifestyles of wealthy people, etc. The syllabus was an accurate description of all we learned.

We learned about privilege, wealthy people, their secrets, family structures, family drama, histories of privilege, philanthropy, wealth planning, wealth hoarding, and parenting practices of the ultra rich.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The balance of lecture/discussion in class, as well as the variety of types of work that go into the grade, created a good mix of depth and breadth.
I really enjoyed the assignments (especially the wealthy person interview)! They were creative and a manageable amount of work.

Strengths-the professor was a great lecturer, and the topic is very interesting!
Weaknesses-a lot of reading, did not provide a lot of  "what's next" for how to contest the problem of wealth in the Americas, other than through academia (I did appreciate the visit from RG but wished we had also critically talked about organizations such as RG).
The strength of the course is that you will learn a lot. The weaknesses are the assignments. The assignments were not clear and were very harshly graded.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course - I feel that it teaches a variety of lenses through which to teach wealth. We all interact with wealth, and this class has plenty for everyone to get out of it.  It's the type of course that anyone should take.
Yes! A great course to take if you're interested in sociology/anthropology within ER&M.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student, especially at institutions like Yale. Yale is one of the quintessential examples of wealth, and we are all very privileged to be here. I think it is important to understand what role we play in contesting/supporting wealth inequality.
yes, Professor Ramos-Zayas is extremely skilled and talented

Yes! Professor Ramos-Zayas is amazing and the class topics were incredibly interesting. I have never taken a course on elite studies and so I learned so much. The readings were great, class lectures were great, and overall learned so much.
